comments: The compositions of n  in which each natural number is colored by one of  p different colors are called p-colored compositions of n.  For n>=2, 10*a(n-2) equals the number of  10-colored compositions of n with all parts >=2, such that  no adjacent parts have  the same color. - _Milan Janjic_, Nov 26 2011

formula: a(n) = (((1+sqrt(37))/2)^(n+1) - ((1-sqrt(37))/2)^(n+1))/sqrt(37).a(n) = sum{k=0..floor(n/2), binomial(n-k, k)*9^k }. - _Paul Barry_, Jul 20 2004a(n) = sum{k=0..n, binomial((n+k)/2, (n-k)/2)*(1+(-1)^(n-k))*3^(n-k)/2}. - _Paul Barry_, Aug 28 2005a(n) = sum(k=0..n, A109466(n,k)*(-9)^(n-k) ). [From _Philippe Deléham_, Oct 26 2008]a(n) = (1/37)*(1/2+(1/2)*sqrt(37))^n*sqrt(37)-(1/37)*(1/2-(1/2)*sqrt(37))^n*sqrt(37). [From Paolo P. Lava, Oct 01 2008] [May produce sequence with a different offset.]G.f.: (-9*x-1)/(9*x^2+x-1) a(n)=(-703*(1/2-sqrt(37)/2)^n + 199*sqrt(37)*(1/2-sqrt(37)/2)^n-333*(1/2+sqrt(37)/2)^n + 171*sqrt(37)*(1/2+sqrt(37)/2)^n)/(74*(5*sqrt(37)-14)). [From Alexander R. Povolotsky, Oct 13 2010]a(n) = (sum{1<=k<=n+1, k odd}C(n+1,k)*37^((k-1)/2))/2^n. - _Vladimir Shevelev_, Feb 05 2014
